016package tech.uom.seshat;
017
018import javax.measure.Dimension;
019import javax.measure.Unit;
020import javax.measure.UnitConverter;
021import javax.measure.format.ParserException;
022import javax.measure.Quantity;
023import javax.measure.quantity.*;
024import javax.measure.quantity.Angle;
025import tech.uom.seshat.resources.Errors;
026
027import static tech.uom.seshat.UnitRegistry.SI;
028import static tech.uom.seshat.UnitRegistry.ACCEPTED;
029import static tech.uom.seshat.UnitRegistry.IMPERIAL;
030import static tech.uom.seshat.UnitRegistry.OTHER;
031import static tech.uom.seshat.UnitRegistry.PREFIXABLE;
032
033
034/**
035 * Provides constants for various Units of Measurement together with static methods working on {@link Unit} instances.
036 * This class focuses on the most commonly used units in the geospatial domain:
037 * angular units ({@linkplain #DEGREE degree}, {@linkplain #ARC_SECOND arc-second}, …),
038 * linear units ({@linkplain #KILOMETRE kilometre}, {@linkplain #NAUTICAL_MILE nautical mile}, …) and
039 * temporal units ({@linkplain #DAY day}, {@linkplain #TROPICAL_YEAR year}, …),
040 * but some other kind of units are also provided for completeness.
041 * The main quantities are listed below, together with some related units:
042 *
043 * <table class="sis">
044 *   <caption>Some quantities and related units</caption>
045 *   <tr><th colspan="2">Quantity type</th><th>System unit</th><th>Some conventional units</th></tr>
046 *
047 *   <tr><td style="padding-top:15px" colspan="4"><b>Fundamental:</b></td></tr>
048 *   <tr><td>{@link Length}</td>            <td>(L)</td> <td>{@link #METRE}</td>    <td>{@link #CENTIMETRE}, {@link #KILOMETRE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #FOOT}</td></tr>
049 *   <tr><td>{@link Mass}</td>              <td>(M)</td> <td>{@link #KILOGRAM}</td> <td></td></tr>
050 *   <tr><td>{@link Time}</td>              <td>(T)</td> <td>{@link #SECOND}</td>   <td>{@link #MILLISECOND}, {@link #MINUTE}, {@link #HOUR}, {@link #DAY}, {@link #WEEK}, {@link #TROPICAL_YEAR}</td></tr>
051 *   <tr><td>{@link ElectricCurrent}</td>   <td>(I)</td> <td>{@link #AMPERE}</td>   <td></td></tr>
052 *   <tr><td>{@link Temperature}</td>       <td>(Θ)</td> <td>{@link #KELVIN}</td>   <td>{@link #CELSIUS}, {@link #FAHRENHEIT}</td></tr>
053 *   <tr><td>{@link AmountOfSubstance}</td> <td>(N)</td> <td>{@link #MOLE}</td>     <td></td></tr>
054 *   <tr><td>{@link LuminousIntensity}</td> <td>(J)</td> <td>{@link #CANDELA}</td>  <td></td></tr>
055 *
056 *   <tr><td style="padding-top:15px" colspan="4"><b>Dimensionless:</b></td></tr>
057 *   <tr><td>{@link Angle}</td>      <td></td> <td>{@link #RADIAN}</td>    <td>{@link #DEGREE}, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, {@link #GRAD}</td></tr>
058 *   <tr><td>{@link SolidAngle}</td> <td></td> <td>{@link #STERADIAN}</td> <td></td></tr>
059 *
060 *   <tr><td style="padding-top:15px" colspan="4"><b>Derived:</b></td></tr>
061 *   <tr><td>{@link Area}</td>     <td>(A)</td> <td>{@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td>      <td>{@link #HECTARE}</td></tr>
062 *   <tr><td>{@link Volume}</td>   <td>(V)</td> <td>{@link #CUBIC_METRE}</td>       <td></td></tr>
063 *   <tr><td>{@link Speed}</td>    <td>(ν)</td> <td>{@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}</td> <td>{@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}</td></tr>
064 *   <tr><td>{@link Pressure}</td> <td></td>    <td>{@link #PASCAL}</td>            <td>{@link #HECTOPASCAL}, {@link #DECIBAR}, {@link #BAR}, {@link #ATMOSPHERE}</td></tr>
065 * </table>
066 *
067 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (IRD, Geomatys)
068 * @version 1.0
069 */
070public final class Units {
071    /**
072     * Unit of measurement defined as 10<sup>-9</sup> metres (1 nm).
073     * This unit is often used in wavelength measurements.
074     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
075     * and the unlocalized name is "nanometre".
076     *
077     * <div class="note">
078     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
079     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
080     *   <tr><td>SI units:</td>         <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code NANOMETRE}</u>, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
081     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
082     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
083     * </table></div>
084     */
085    public static final Unit<Length> NANOMETRE;
086
087    /**
088     * Unit of measurement defined as 0.001 metres (1 mm).
089     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
090     * and the unlocalized name is “millimetre”.
091     *
092     * <div class="note">
093     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
094     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
095     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, <u>{@code MILLIMETRE}</u>, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
096     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
097     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
098     * </table></div>
099     */
100    public static final Unit<Length> MILLIMETRE;
101
102    /**
103     * Unit of measurement defined as 0.01 metres (1 cm).
104     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
105     * and the unlocalized name is “centimetre”.
106     *
107     * <div class="note">
108     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
109     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
110     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, <u>{@code CENTIMETRE}</u>, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
111     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
112     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
113     * </table></div>
114     */
115    public static final Unit<Length> CENTIMETRE;
116
117    /**
118     * The SI base unit for distances (m).
119     * The unlocalized name is “metre”.
120     * This is the base of all other {@linkplain #isLinear(Unit) linear} units.
121     *
122     * <div class="note">
123     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
124     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
125     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <u><b>{@code METRE}</b></u>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
126     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
127     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
128     * </table></div>
129     */
130    public static final Unit<Length> METRE;
131
132    /**
133     * Unit of measurement defined as 1000 metres (1 km).
134     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
135     * and the unlocalized name is “kilometre”.
136     *
137     * <div class="note">
138     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
139     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
140     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, <u>{@code KILOMETRE}</u>.</td></tr>
141     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
142     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}.</td></tr>
143     * </table></div>
144     */
145    public static final Unit<Length> KILOMETRE;
146
147    /**
148     * Unit of measurement defined as exactly 1852 metres (1 M).
149     * This is approximately the distance between two parallels of latitude
150     * separated by one {@linkplain #ARC_MINUTE arc-minute}.
151     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
152     * and the unlocalized name is “nautical mile”.
153     *
154     * <p>There is no internationally agreed symbol for nautical mile. Seshat uses “M” in agreement with the
155     * International Hydrographic Organization (IHO) and the International Bureau of Weights and Measures (BIPM).
156     * But “NM” and “nmi” are also in use.</p>
157     *
158     * <div class="note">
159     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
160     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
161     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
162     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, <u>{@code NAUTICAL_MILE}</u>.</td></tr>
163     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}.</td></tr>
164     * </table></div>
165     */
166    public static final Unit<Length> NAUTICAL_MILE;
167
168    /**
169     * Unit of measurement defined as exactly 1609.344 metres (1 mi).
170     * This unit is often named “mile” without qualifier, but Seshat uses “statute mile”
171     * for emphasing the difference with {@linkplain #NAUTICAL_MILE nautical mile}.
172     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}.
173     * The unlocalized name is “statute mile” but is localized as "international mile" in the US
174     * for avoiding confusion with the US survey mile.
175     *
176     * <div class="note">
177     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
178     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
179     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
180     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, <u>{@code STATUTE_MILE}</u>, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
181     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}.</td></tr>
182     * </table></div>
183     */
184    public static final Unit<Length> STATUTE_MILE;
185
186    /**
187     * Unit of measurement approximately equals to 0.3048006096… metres.
188     * The legal definition is exactly 12/39.37 metres.
189     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
190     * and the unlocalized name is “US survey foot”.
191     *
192     * <div class="note">
193     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
194     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
195     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
196     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, <u>{@code US_SURVEY_FOOT}</u>, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
197     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
198     * </table></div>
199     */
200    public static final Unit<Length> US_SURVEY_FOOT;
201
202    /**
203     * Unit of measurement defined as 0.3047972654 metres.
204     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
205     * and the unlocalized name is “Clarke’s foot”.
206     *
207     * <div class="note">
208     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
209     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
210     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
211     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, <u>{@code CLARKE_FOOT}</u>, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
212     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
213     * </table></div>
214     */
215    public static final Unit<Length> CLARKE_FOOT;
216
217    /**
218     * Unit of measurement defined as exactly 0.3048 metres (1 ft).
219     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
220     * and the unlocalized name is “foot”.
221     *
222     * <div class="note">
223     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
224     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
225     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
226     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, {@link #INCH}, <u>{@code FOOT}</u>, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
227     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
228     * </table></div>
229     */
230    public static final Unit<Length> FOOT;
231
232    /**
233     * Unit of measurement defined as 2.54 centimetres (1 in).
234     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
235     * and the unlocalized name is “inch”.
236     *
237     * <div class="note">
238     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
239     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
240     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
241     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #POINT}, <u>{@code INCH}</u>, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
242     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
243     * </table></div>
244     */
245    public static final Unit<Length> INCH;
246
247    /**
248     * Unit of measurement defined as 0.013837 inch (1 pt).
249     * This is commonly used to measure the height of a font.
250     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRE}
251     * and the unlocalized name is “point”.
252     *
253     * <div class="note">
254     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
255     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
256     *   <tr><td>SI length units:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #NANOMETRE}, {@link #MILLIMETRE}, {@link #CENTIMETRE}, <b>{@link #METRE}</b>, {@link #KILOMETRE}.</td></tr>
257     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code POINT}</u>, {@link #INCH}, {@link #FOOT}, {@link #CLARKE_FOOT}, {@link #US_SURVEY_FOOT}, {@link #STATUTE_MILE}, {@link #NAUTICAL_MILE}.</td></tr>
258     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SQUARE_METRE}, {@link #CUBIC_METRE}, {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}.</td></tr>
259     * </table></div>
260     */
261    public static final Unit<Length> POINT;
262
263    /**
264     * The SI derived unit for area (m²).
265     * The unlocalized name is “square metre”.
266     *
267     * <div class="note">
268     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
269     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
270     *   <tr><td>SI area units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u><b>{@code SQUARE_METRE}</b></u>, {@link #HECTARE}.</td></tr>
271     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #CUBIC_METRE}.</td></tr>
272     * </table></div>
273     */
274    public static final Unit<Area> SQUARE_METRE;
275
276    /**
277     * Unit of measurement defined as 10,000 square metres (1 ha).
278     * One hectare is exactly equals to one hectometre (1 hm²).
279     * While not an SI unit, the hectare is often used in the measurement of land.
280     * The unlocalized name is “hectare”.
281     *
282     * <div class="note">
283     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
284     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
285     *   <tr><td>SI area units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #SQUARE_METRE}</b>, <u>{@code HECTARE}</u>.</td></tr>
286     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #CUBIC_METRE}.</td></tr>
287     * </table></div>
288     */
289    public static final Unit<Area> HECTARE;
290
291    /**
292     * The SI derived unit for volume (m³).
293     * The unlocalized name is “cubic metre”.
294     */
295    public static final Unit<Volume> CUBIC_METRE;
296
297    /**
298     * The unit for litre volume (L, l or ℓ).
299     * The unlocalized name is “litre”.
300     */
301    public static final Unit<Volume> LITRE;
302
303    /**
304     * The SI unit for solid angles (sr).
305     * The unlocalized name is “steradian”.
306     */
307    public static final Unit<SolidAngle> STERADIAN;
308
309    /**
310     * Unit of measurement defined as 10<sup>-6</sup> radians (1 µrad).
311     * The distance of one microradian of latitude on Earth is approximately 2 millimetres.
312     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #RADIAN}
313     * and the unlocalized name is “microradian”.
314     *
315     * <div class="note">
316     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
317     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
318     *   <tr><td>SI angle units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code MICRORADIAN}</u>, <b>{@link #RADIAN}</b>.</td></tr>
319     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DEGREE}, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, {@link #GRAD}.</td></tr>
320     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
321     * </table></div>
322     */
323    public static final Unit<Angle> MICRORADIAN;
324
325    /**
326     * The SI unit for plane angles (rad).
327     * There is 2π radians in a circle.
328     * The unlocalized name is “radian”.
329     * This is the base of all other {@linkplain #isAngular(Unit) angular} units.
330     *
331     * <div class="note">
332     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
333     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
334     *   <tr><td>SI angle units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MICRORADIAN}, <u><b>{@code RADIAN}</b></u>.</td></tr>
335     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DEGREE}, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, {@link #GRAD}.</td></tr>
336     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
337     * </table></div>
338     */
339    public static final Unit<Angle> RADIAN;
340
341    /**
342     * Unit of measurement defined as π/180 radians (1°).
343     * There is 360° in a circle.
344     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #RADIAN}
345     * and the unlocalized name is “degree”.
346     *
347     * <div class="note">
348     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
349     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
350     *   <tr><td>SI angle units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MICRORADIAN}, <b>{@link #RADIAN}</b>.</td></tr>
351     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code DEGREE}</u>, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, {@link #GRAD}.</td></tr>
352     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
353     * </table></div>
354     */
355    public static final Unit<Angle> DEGREE;
356
357    /**
358     * Unit of measurement defined as 1/60 degree (1′).
359     * The distance of one arc-minute of latitude on Earth is approximately 1852 metres
360     * (one {@linkplain #NAUTICAL_MILE nautical mile}).
361     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #RADIAN}
362     * and the unlocalized name is “arc-minute”.
363     *
364     * <div class="note">
365     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
366     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
367     *   <tr><td>SI angle units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MICRORADIAN}, <b>{@link #RADIAN}</b>.</td></tr>
368     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DEGREE}, <u>{@code ARC_MINUTE}</u>, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, {@link #GRAD}.</td></tr>
369     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
370     * </table></div>
371     */
372    public static final Unit<Angle> ARC_MINUTE;
373
374    /**
375     * Unit of measurement defined as 1/(60×60) degree (1″).
376     * The distance of one arc-second of latitude on Earth is approximately 31 metres.
377     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #RADIAN}
378     * and the unlocalized name is “arc-second”.
379     *
380     * <div class="note">
381     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
382     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
383     *   <tr><td>SI angle units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MICRORADIAN}, <b>{@link #RADIAN}</b>.</td></tr>
384     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DEGREE}, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, <u>{@code ARC_SECOND}</u>, {@link #GRAD}.</td></tr>
385     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
386     * </table></div>
387     */
388    public static final Unit<Angle> ARC_SECOND;
389
390    /**
391     * Unit of measurement defined as π/200 radians (1 grad).
392     * There is 400 grads in a circle.
393     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #RADIAN},
394     * the unlocalized name is “grad”, but the “gon” alias is also accepted.
395     *
396     * <div class="note">
397     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
398     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
399     *   <tr><td>SI angle units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MICRORADIAN}, <b>{@link #RADIAN}</b>.</td></tr>
400     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DEGREE}, {@link #ARC_MINUTE}, {@link #ARC_SECOND}, <u>{@code GRAD}</u>.</td></tr>
401     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #STERADIAN}.</td></tr>
402     * </table></div>
403     */
404    public static final Unit<Angle> GRAD;
405
406    /**
407     * Unit of measurement defined as 10<sup>-3</sup> seconds (1 ms).
408     * This unit is useful for inter-operability with various methods from the standard Java library.
409     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #SECOND}
410     * and the unlocalized name is “millisecond”.
411     *
412     * <div class="note">
413     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
414     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
415     *   <tr><td>SI time units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code MILLISECOND}</u>, <b>{@link #SECOND}</b>.</td></tr>
416     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MINUTE}, {@link #HOUR}, {@link #DAY}, {@link #WEEK}, {@link #TROPICAL_YEAR}.</td></tr>
417     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}, {@link #HERTZ}.</td></tr>
418     * </table></div>
419     *
420     * @see java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit#MILLISECONDS
421     */
422    public static final Unit<Time> MILLISECOND;
423
424    /**
425     * The SI base unit for durations (s).
426     * The unlocalized name is “second”.
427     * This is the base of all other {@linkplain #isTemporal(Unit) temporal} units.
428     *
429     * <div class="note">
430     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
431     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
432     *   <tr><td>SI time units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MILLISECOND}, <u><b>{@link #SECOND}</b></u>.</td></tr>
433     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MINUTE}, {@link #HOUR}, {@link #DAY}, {@link #WEEK}, {@link #TROPICAL_YEAR}.</td></tr>
434     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}, {@link #HERTZ}.</td></tr>
435     * </table></div>
436     */
437    public static final Unit<Time> SECOND;
438
439    /**
440     * Unit of measurement defined as 60 seconds (1 min).
441     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #SECOND}
442     * and the unlocalized name is “minute”.
443     *
444     * <div class="note">
445     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">

448     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code MINUTE}</u>, {@link #HOUR}, {@link #DAY}, {@link #WEEK}, {@link #TROPICAL_YEAR}.</td></tr>
449     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}, {@link #HERTZ}.</td></tr>
450     * </table></div>

454    /**
455     * Unit of measurement defined as 60×60 seconds (1 h).
456     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #SECOND}
457     * and the unlocalized name is “hour”.

463     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MINUTE}, <u>{@code HOUR}</u>, {@link #DAY}, {@link #WEEK}, {@link #TROPICAL_YEAR}.</td></tr>

472     * and the unlocalized name is “day”.
473     *
474     * <div class="note">
475     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
