484    /**
485     * Unit of measurement defined as 7 days (1 wk).
486     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #SECOND}
487     * and the unlocalized name is “week”.
488     *
489     * <div class="note">
490     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
491     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
492     *   <tr><td>SI time units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MILLISECOND}, <b>{@link #SECOND}</b>.</td></tr>
493     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MINUTE}, {@link #HOUR}, {@link #DAY}, <u>{@link #WEEK}</u>, {@link #TROPICAL_YEAR}.</td></tr>
494     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}, {@link #HERTZ}.</td></tr>
495     * </table></div>
496     */
497    public static final Unit<Time> WEEK;
498
499    /**
500     * Unit of measurement approximately equals to 365.24219 days (1 a).
501     * This is defined by the International Union of Geological Sciences (IUGS) as exactly 31556925.445 seconds,
502     * taken as the length of the tropical year in the the year 2000.
503     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #SECOND},
504     * the unlocalized name is “year”.
505     *
506     * <div class="note">
507     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
508     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
509     *   <tr><td>SI time units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MILLISECOND}, <b>{@link #SECOND}</b>.</td></tr>
510     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #MINUTE}, {@link #HOUR}, {@link #DAY}, {@link #WEEK}, <u>{@code TROPICAL_YEAR}</u>.</td></tr>
511     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}, {@link #HERTZ}.</td></tr>
512     * </table></div>
513     */
514    public static final Unit<Time> TROPICAL_YEAR;
515
516    /**
517     * The SI derived unit for frequency (Hz).
518     * One hertz is equal to one cycle per {@linkplain #SECOND second}.
519     * The unlocalized name is “hertz”.
520     *
521     * <div class="note">
522     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
523     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
524     *   <tr><td>Components:</td><td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #SECOND}<sup>-1</sup></td></tr>
525     * </table></div>
526     */
527    public static final Unit<Frequency> HERTZ;
528
529    /**
530     * The SI derived unit for speed (m/s).
531     * The unlocalized name is “metres per second”.
532     *
533     * <div class="note">
534     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
535     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
536     *   <tr><td>SI speed units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u><b>{@code METRES_PER_SECOND}</b></u>.</td></tr>
537     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}.</td></tr>
538     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>       <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #METRE} ∕ {@link #SECOND}</td></tr>
539     * </table></div>
540     */
541    public static final Unit<Speed> METRES_PER_SECOND;
542
543    /**
544     * Unit of measurement defined as 1/3.6 metres per second (1 km/h).
545     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}
546     * and the unlocalized name is “kilometres per hour”.
547     *
548     * <div class="note">
549     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
550     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
551     *   <tr><td>SI speed units:</td>   <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #METRES_PER_SECOND}</b>.</td></tr>
552     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR}</u>.</td></tr>
553     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>       <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #KILOMETRE} ∕ {@link #HOUR}</td></tr>
554     * </table></div>
555     */
556    public static final Unit<Speed> KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR;
557
558    /**
559     * The SI derived unit for pressure (Pa).
560     * One pascal is equal to 1 N/m².
561     * Pressures are often used for height measurements on a vertical axis.
562     * The unlocalized name is “pascal”.
563     *
564     * <div class="note">
565     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
566     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
567     *   <tr><td>SI pressure units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u><b>{@code PASCAL}</b></u>, {@link #HECTOPASCAL}.</td></tr>
568     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DECIBAR}, {@link #BAR}, {@link #ATMOSPHERE}.</td></tr>
569     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>        <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
570     * </table></div>
571     */
572    public static final Unit<Pressure> PASCAL;
573
574    /**
575     * Unit of measurement defined as 100 pascals (1 hPa).
576     * The hectopascal is the international unit for measuring atmospheric or barometric pressure
577     * and is exactly equal to one millibar.
578     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #PASCAL}
579     * and the unlocalized name is “hectopascal”.
580     *
581     * <div class="note">
582     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
583     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
584     *   <tr><td>SI pressure units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #PASCAL}</b>, <u>{@code HECTOPASCAL}</u>.</td></tr>
585     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DECIBAR}, {@link #BAR}, {@link #ATMOSPHERE}.</td></tr>
586     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>        <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
587     * </table></div>
588     */
589    public static final Unit<Pressure> HECTOPASCAL;
590
591    /**
592     * Unit of measurement defined as 10000 pascals (1 dbar).
593     * This unit is used in oceanography as there is an approximate numerical equivalence
594     * between pressure changes in decibars and depth changes in metres underwater.
595     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #PASCAL}
596     * and the unlocalized name is “decibar”.
597     *
598     * <div class="note">
599     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
600     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
601     *   <tr><td>SI pressure units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #PASCAL}</b>, {@link #HECTOPASCAL}.</td></tr>
602     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code DECIBAR}</u>, {@link #BAR}, {@link #ATMOSPHERE}.</td></tr>
603     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>        <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
604     * </table></div>
605     */
606    public static final Unit<Pressure> DECIBAR;
607
608    /**
609     * Unit of measurement defined as 100000 pascals (1 bar).
610     * One bar is slightly less than the average atmospheric pressure on Earth at sea level.
611     * One millibar is exactly equal to one {@linkplain #HECTOPASCAL hectopascal}.
612     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #PASCAL}
613     * and the unlocalized name is “bar”.
614     *
615     * <div class="note">
616     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
617     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
618     *   <tr><td>SI pressure units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #PASCAL}</b>, {@link #HECTOPASCAL}.</td></tr>
619     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DECIBAR}, <u>{@code BAR}</u>, {@link #ATMOSPHERE}.</td></tr>
620     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>        <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
621     * </table></div>
622     */
623    public static final Unit<Pressure> BAR;
624
625    /**
626     * Unit of measurement defined as 101325 pascals (1 atm).
627     * One atmosphere reflects the pressure at the mean sea level for countries around 49°N of latitude.
628     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #PASCAL}
629     * and the unlocalized name is “atmosphere”.
630     *
631     * <div class="note">
632     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
633     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
634     *   <tr><td>SI pressure units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #PASCAL}</b>, {@link #HECTOPASCAL}.</td></tr>
635     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>  <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #DECIBAR}, {@link #BAR}, <u>{@code ATMOSPHERE}</u>.</td></tr>
636     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>        <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
637     * </table></div>
638     */
639    public static final Unit<Pressure> ATMOSPHERE;
640
641    /**
642     * The SI derived unit for force (N).
643     * One newton is the force required to give a mass of 1 kg an acceleration of 1 m/s².
644     * The unlocalized name is “newton”.
645     *
646     * <div class="note">
647     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
648     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
649     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #KILOGRAM} ⋅ {@link #METRES_PER_SECOND} ∕ {@link #SECOND}</td></tr>
650     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #PASCAL}, {@link #JOULE}, {@link #WATT}.</td></tr>
651     * </table></div>
652     */
653    public static final Unit<Force> NEWTON;
654
655    /**
656     * The SI derived unit for energy (J).
657     * The unlocalized name is “joule”.
658     *
659     * <div class="note">
660     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
661     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
662     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #NEWTON} ⋅ {@link #METRE}</td></tr>
663     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #WATT}.</td></tr>
664     * </table></div>
665     */
666    public static final Unit<Energy> JOULE;
667
668    /**
669     * The SI derived unit for power (W).
670     * One watt is equal to one joule per second.
671     * The unlocalized name is “watt”.
672     *
673     * <div class="note">
674     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
675     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
676     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #JOULE} ∕ {@link #SECOND}</td></tr>
677     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #VOLT}.</td></tr>
678     * </table></div>
679     */
680    public static final Unit<Power> WATT;
681
682    /**
683     * The SI derived unit for electric potential difference (V).
684     * The unlocalized name is “volt”.
685     *
686     * <div class="note">
687     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
688     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
689     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #WATT} ∕ {@link #AMPERE}</td></tr>
690     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #FARAD}, {@link #OHM}, {@link #SIEMENS}, {@link #WEBER}.</td></tr>
691     * </table></div>
692     */
693    public static final Unit<ElectricPotential> VOLT;
694
695    /**
696     * The SI base unit for electric current (A).
697     * The unlocalized name is “ampere”.
698     *
699     * <div class="note">
700     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
701     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
702     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #COULOMB}, {@link #VOLT}, {@link #OHM}, {@link #SIEMENS}, {@link #HENRY}.</td></tr>
703     * </table></div>
704     */
705    public static final Unit<ElectricCurrent> AMPERE;
706
707    /**
708     * The SI derived unit for electric charge (C).
709     * One coulomb is the charge transfered by a current of one ampere during one second.
710     * The unlocalized name is “coulomb”.
711     *
712     * <div class="note">
713     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
714     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
715     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #AMPERE} ⋅ {@link #SECOND}</td></tr>
716     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #FARAD}.</td></tr>
717     * </table></div>
718     */
719    public static final Unit<ElectricCharge> COULOMB;
720
721    /**
722     * The SI derived unit for electric capacitance (F).
723     * The unlocalized name is “farad”.
724     *
725     * <div class="note">
726     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
727     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
728     *   <tr><td>Components:</td> <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #COULOMB} ∕ {@link #VOLT}</td></tr>
729     * </table></div>
730     */
731    public static final Unit<ElectricCapacitance> FARAD;
732
733    /**
734     * The SI derived unit for electric resistance (Ω).
735     * This is the inverse of electric conductance.
736     * The unlocalized name is “ohm”.
737     *
738     * <div class="note">
739     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
740     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
741     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #VOLT} ∕ {@link #AMPERE}</td></tr>
742     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #SIEMENS}.</td></tr>
743     * </table></div>
744     */
745    public static final Unit<ElectricResistance> OHM;
746
747    /**
748     * The SI derived unit for electric conductance (S).
749     * This is the inverse of electric resistance.
750     * The unlocalized name is “siemens”.
751     *
752     * <div class="note">
753     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
754     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
755     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #AMPERE} ∕ {@link #VOLT}</td></tr>
756     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #OHM}.</td></tr>
757     * </table></div>
758     */
759    public static final Unit<ElectricConductance> SIEMENS;
760
761    /**
762     * The SI derived unit for magnetic flux (Wb).
763     * The unlocalized name is “weber”.
764     *
765     * <div class="note">
766     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
767     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
768     *   <tr><td>Components:</td>    <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #VOLT} ⋅ {@link #SECOND}</td></tr>
769     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #TESLA}, {@link #HENRY}.</td></tr>
770     * </table></div>
771     */
772    public static final Unit<MagneticFlux> WEBER;
773
774    /**
775     * The SI derived unit for magnetic flux density (T).
776     * The unlocalized name is “tesla”.
777     *
778     * <div class="note">
779     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
780     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
781     *   <tr><td>Components:</td> <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #WEBER} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
782     * </table></div>
783     */
784    public static final Unit<MagneticFluxDensity> TESLA;
785
786    /**
787     * The SI derived unit for inductance (H).
788     * The unlocalized name is “henry”.
789     *
790     * <div class="note">
791     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
792     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
793     *   <tr><td>Components:</td> <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #WEBER} ∕ {@link #AMPERE}</td></tr>
794     * </table></div>
795     */
796    public static final Unit<ElectricInductance> HENRY;
797
798    /**
799     * The SI base unit for thermodynamic temperature (K).
800     * The unlocalized name is “kelvin”.
801     *
802     * <div class="note">
803     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
804     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
805     *   <tr><td>SI temperature units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u><b>{@code KELVIN}</b></u>.</td></tr>
806     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>     <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #CELSIUS}, {@link #FAHRENHEIT}.</td></tr>
807     * </table></div>
808     */
809    public static final Unit<Temperature> KELVIN;
810
811    /**
812     * Unit of measurement defined as the temperature in Kelvin minus 273.15.
813     * The symbol is °C and the unlocalized name is “Celsius”.
814     * Note that this is the only SI unit with an upper-case letter in its name.
815     *
816     * <div class="note">
817     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
818     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
819     *   <tr><td>SI temperature units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #KELVIN}</b>.</td></tr>
820     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>     <td style="word-spacing:1em"><u>{@code CELSIUS}</u>, {@link #FAHRENHEIT}.</td></tr>
821     * </table></div>
822     */
823    public static final Unit<Temperature> CELSIUS;
824
825    /**
826     * Unit of measurement defined as 1.8 degree Celsius plus 32.
827     * The symbol is °F and the unlocalized name is “Fahrenheit”
828     * (note the upper-case "F" letter).
829     *
830     * <div class="note">
831     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
832     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
833     *   <tr><td>SI temperature units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em"><b>{@link #KELVIN}</b>.</td></tr>
834     *   <tr><td>In other systems:</td>     <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #CELSIUS}, <u>{@code FAHRENHEIT}</u>.</td></tr>
835     * </table></div>
836     */
837    public static final Unit<Temperature> FAHRENHEIT;
838
839    /**
840     * The SI base unit for luminous intensity (cd).
841     * The unlocalized name is “candela”.
842     *
843     * <div class="note">
844     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
845     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
846     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #LUMEN}, {@link #LUX}.</td></tr>
847     * </table></div>
848     */
849    public static final Unit<LuminousIntensity> CANDELA;
850
851    /**
852     * The SI derived unit for luminous flux (lm).
853     * The unlocalized name is “lumen”.
854     *
855     * <div class="note">
856     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
857     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
858     *   <tr><td>Components:</td> <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #CANDELA} ⋅ {@link #STERADIAN}</td></tr>
859     *   <tr><td>Derived units:</td> <td style="word-spacing:1em">{@link #LUX}.</td></tr>
860     * </table></div>
861     */
862    public static final Unit<LuminousFlux> LUMEN;
863
864    /**
865     * The SI derived unit for illuminance (lx).
866     * The unlocalized name is “lux”.
867     *
868     * <div class="note">
869     * <table class="compact" style="margin-left:30px; line-height:1.25">
870     *   <caption>Related units</caption>
871     *   <tr><td>Components:</td> <td style="word-spacing:0.5em">{@link #LUX} ∕ {@link #SQUARE_METRE}</td></tr>
872     * </table></div>
873     */
874    public static final Unit<Illuminance> LUX;
875
876    /**
877     * A SI conventional unit for mass (g).
878     * The unlocalized name is “gram”.
879     */
880    public static final Unit<Mass> GRAM;
881
882    /**
883     * The SI base unit for mass (kg).
884     * The unlocalized name is “kilogram”.
885     */
886    public static final Unit<Mass> KILOGRAM;
887
888    /**
889     * The SI base unit for amount of substance (mol).
890     * The unlocalized name is “mole”.
891     */
892    public static final Unit<AmountOfSubstance> MOLE;
893
894    /**
895     * The base dimensionless unit for scale measurements.
896     * The unlocalized name is “unity”.
897     * This is the base of all other {@linkplain #isScale(Unit) scale} units:
898     *
899     * {@link #PERCENT} (%),
900     * {@link #PPM} (ppm) and
901     * {@link #PIXEL} (px)
902     * among others.
903     */
904    public static final Unit<Dimensionless> UNITY;
905
906    /**
907     * Dimensionless unit for percentages (%).
908     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #UNITY}
909     * and the unlocalized name is “percentage”.
910     *
911     * @see #UNITY
912     * @see #PPM
913     */
914    public static final Unit<Dimensionless> PERCENT;
915
916    /**
917     * Dimensionless unit for parts per million (ppm).
918     * The {@linkplain ConventionalUnit#getSystemUnit() system unit} is {@link #UNITY},
919     * the unlocalized name is “parts per million”.
920     *
921     * @see #UNITY
922     * @see #PERCENT
923     */
924    public static final Unit<Dimensionless> PPM;
925
926    /**
927     * Sub-division of logarithm of ratio of the measured quantity to a reference quantity (dB).
928     */
929    public static final Unit<Dimensionless> DECIBEL;
930
931    /**
932     * Dimensionless unit for pixels (px).
933     * The unlocalized name is “pixel”.
934     * This unity should not be confused with {@link #POINT}, which is approximately equal to 1/72 of inch.
935     *
936     * @see #POINT
937     */
938    public static final Unit<Dimensionless> PIXEL;
939
940    /**
941     * Sets to {@code true} by the static initializer after the initialization has been completed.
942     * This is a safety against unexpected changes in the {@link UnitRegistry#HARD_CODED} map.
943     *
944     * <p>We use here a "lazy final initialization" pattern. We rely on the fact that this field is
945     * initialized to {@code true} only at the end of the following static initializer. All methods
946     * invoked in the static initializer will see the default value, which is {@code false}, until
947     * the initializer fully completed. While apparently dangerous, this behavior is actually documented
948     * in <a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-12.html#jls-12.4.1">section 12.4.1
949     * of Java language specification</a>:</p>
950     *
951     * <blockquote>The fact that initialization code is unrestricted allows examples to be constructed where
952     * the value of a class variable can be observed when it still has its initial default value, before its
953     * initializing expression is evaluated, but such examples are rare in practice. (…snip…) The full power
954     * of the Java programming language is available in these initializers; programmers must exercise some care.
955     * This power places an extra burden on code generators, but this burden would arise in any case because
956     * the Java programming language is concurrent.</blockquote>
957     */
958    static final boolean initialized;
959    static {
960        final UnitDimension length        = new UnitDimension('L');
961        final UnitDimension mass          = new UnitDimension('M');
962        final UnitDimension time          = new UnitDimension('T');
963        final UnitDimension current       = new UnitDimension('I');
964        final UnitDimension temperature   = new UnitDimension('Θ');
965        final UnitDimension amount        = new UnitDimension('N');
966        final UnitDimension luminous      = new UnitDimension('J');
967        final UnitDimension frequency     = time.pow(-1);
968        final UnitDimension area          = length.pow(2);
969        final UnitDimension speed         = length.divide(time);
970        final UnitDimension force         = mass.multiply(speed).divide(time);
971        final UnitDimension energy        = force.multiply(length);
972        final UnitDimension power         = energy.divide(time);
973        final UnitDimension charge        = current.multiply(time);
974        final UnitDimension potential     = power.divide(current);
975        final UnitDimension magneticFlux  = potential.multiply(time);
976        final UnitDimension pressure      = force.divide(area);
977        final UnitDimension dimensionless = UnitDimension.NONE;
978        /*
979         * Base, derived or alternate units that we need to reuse more than once in this static initializer.
980         */
981        final SystemUnit<Length>        m   = add(Length.class,        Scalar.Length::new,         length,        "m",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
982        final SystemUnit<Area>          m2  = add(Area.class,          Scalar.Area::new,           area,          "m²",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
983        final SystemUnit<Volume>        m3  = add(Volume.class,        Scalar.Volume::new,         length.pow(3), "m³",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
984        final SystemUnit<Time>          s   = add(Time.class,          Scalar.Time::new,           time,          "s",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
985        final SystemUnit<Temperature>   K   = add(Temperature.class,   Scalar.Temperature.FACTORY, temperature,   "K",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
986        final SystemUnit<Speed>         mps = add(Speed.class,         Scalar.Speed::new,          speed,         "m∕s", (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
987        final SystemUnit<Pressure>      Pa  = add(Pressure.class,      Scalar.Pressure::new,       pressure,      "Pa",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
988        final SystemUnit<Angle>         rad = add(Angle.class,         Scalar.Angle::new,          dimensionless, "rad", (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
989        final SystemUnit<Dimensionless> one = add(Dimensionless.class, Scalar.Dimensionless::new,  dimensionless, "",            SI);
990        final SystemUnit<Mass>          kg  = add(Mass.class,          Scalar.Mass::new,           mass,          "kg",          SI);
991        /*
992         * All SI prefix to be used below, with additional converters to be used more than once.
993         */
994        final LinearConverter nano  = Prefixes.converter('n');
995        final LinearConverter micro = Prefixes.converter('µ');
996        final LinearConverter milli = Prefixes.converter('m');
997        final LinearConverter centi = Prefixes.converter('c');
998        final LinearConverter hecto = Prefixes.converter('h');
999        final LinearConverter kilo  = Prefixes.converter('k');
1000        final LinearConverter ten4  = LinearConverter.scale(10000, 1);
1001        /*
1002         * All Unit<Angle>.
1003         * 20 is the greatest common denominator between 180 and 200. The intent is to have arguments as small
1004         * as possible in the call to the scale(double, double) method, while keeping the right side integer.
1005         * Staying closer to zero during conversions helo to reduce rounding errors.
1006         */
1007        rad.related(4);
1008        RADIAN      = rad;
1009        GRAD        = add(rad, LinearConverter.scale(Math.PI / 20, 200       / 20), "grad", OTHER);
1010        DEGREE      = add(rad, LinearConverter.scale(Math.PI / 20, 180       / 20), "°",    ACCEPTED);
1011        ARC_MINUTE  = add(rad, LinearConverter.scale(Math.PI / 20, 180*60    / 20), "′",    ACCEPTED);
1012        ARC_SECOND  = add(rad, LinearConverter.scale(Math.PI / 20, 180*60*60 / 20), "″",    ACCEPTED);
1013        MICRORADIAN = add(rad, micro,                                               "µrad", SI);
1014        /*
1015         * All Unit<Length>.
1016         */
1017        m.related(7);
1018        METRE          = m;
1019        NANOMETRE      = add(m, nano,                                     "nm",    SI);
1020        MILLIMETRE     = add(m, milli,                                    "mm",    SI);
1021        CENTIMETRE     = add(m, centi,                                    "cm",    SI);
1022        KILOMETRE      = add(m, kilo,                                     "km",    SI);
1023        NAUTICAL_MILE  = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(   1852,        1), "M",     OTHER);
1024        STATUTE_MILE   = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(1609344,      100), "mi",    IMPERIAL);
1025        US_SURVEY_FOOT = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(   1200,     3937), "ftUS",  OTHER);
1026        CLARKE_FOOT    = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(3047972654d, 1E10), "ftCla", OTHER);
1027        FOOT           = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(   3048,    10000), "ft",    IMPERIAL);
1028        INCH           = add(m, LinearConverter.scale(    254,    10000), "in",    IMPERIAL);
1029        POINT          = add(m, LinearConverter.scale( 996264, 72000000), "pt",    OTHER);
1030        /*
1031         * All Unit<Time>.
1032         */
1033        s.related(5);
1034        SECOND         = s;
1035        MILLISECOND    = add(s, milli,                                      "ms",  SI);
1036        MINUTE         = add(s, LinearConverter.scale(         60,      1), "min", ACCEPTED);
1037        HOUR           = add(s, LinearConverter.scale(      60*60,      1), "h",   ACCEPTED);
1038        DAY            = add(s, LinearConverter.scale(   24*60*60,      1), "d",   ACCEPTED);
1039        WEEK           = add(s, LinearConverter.scale( 7*24*60*60,      1), "wk",  OTHER);
1040        TROPICAL_YEAR  = add(s, LinearConverter.scale(31556925445.0, 1000), "a",   OTHER);
1041        /*
1042         * All Unit<Speed>.
1043         */
1044        mps.related(1);
1045        METRES_PER_SECOND   = mps;
1046        KILOMETRES_PER_HOUR = add(mps, LinearConverter.scale(10, 36), "km∕h", ACCEPTED);
1047        /*
1048         * All Unit<Pressure>.
1049         */
1050        Pa.related(3);
1051        PASCAL      = Pa;
1052        HECTOPASCAL = add(Pa,  hecto,                            "hPa",  SI);
1053        DECIBAR     = add(Pa,  ten4,                             "dbar", OTHER);
1054        BAR         = add(Pa,  LinearConverter.scale(100000, 1), "bar",  OTHER);
1055        ATMOSPHERE  = add(Pa,  LinearConverter.scale(101325, 1), "atm",  OTHER);
1056        /*
1057         * All Unit<Temperature>.
1058         */
1059        K.related(2);
1060        KELVIN       = K;
1061        CELSIUS      = add(K, LinearConverter.offset(  27315, 100), "°C", SI);
1062        FAHRENHEIT   = add(K, new LinearConverter(100, 45967, 180), "°F", OTHER);
1063        /*
1064         * Unit<Volume> and Unit<Mass>. Those units need to be handled in a special way because:
1065         * 1) The base unit of mass is "kg", not "g". This is handled by a hard-coded case in SystemUnit.
1066         * 2) The liter unit is not a SI units, but despite that is commonly used with SI prefixes.
1067         */
1068        SQUARE_METRE = m2;
1069        CUBIC_METRE  = m3;
1070        KILOGRAM     = kg;
1071        HECTARE      = add(m2, ten4,  "ha",        ACCEPTED);
1072        LITRE        = add(m3, milli, "L", (byte) (ACCEPTED | PREFIXABLE));
1073        GRAM         = add(kg, milli, "g", (byte) (ACCEPTED | PREFIXABLE));
1074        /*
1075         * Force, energy, electricity, magnetism and other units.
1076         * Frequency must be defined after angular velocities.
1077         */
1078        HERTZ      = add(Frequency.class,           Scalar.Frequency::new, frequency,                    "Hz",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1079        NEWTON     = add(Force.class,               Scalar.Force::new,     force,                        "N",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1080        JOULE      = add(Energy.class,              Scalar.Energy::new,    energy,                       "J",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1081        WATT       = add(Power.class,               Scalar.Power::new,     power,                        "W",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1082        AMPERE     = add(ElectricCurrent.class,     null,                  current,                      "A",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1083        COULOMB    = add(ElectricCharge.class,      null,                  charge,                       "C",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1084        VOLT       = add(ElectricPotential.class,   null,                  potential,                    "V",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1085        FARAD      = add(ElectricCapacitance.class, null,                  charge.divide(potential),     "F",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1086        SIEMENS    = add(ElectricConductance.class, null,                  current.divide(potential),    "S",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1087        OHM        = add(ElectricResistance.class,  null,                  potential.divide(current),    "Ω",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1088        WEBER      = add(MagneticFlux.class,        null,                  magneticFlux,                 "Wb",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1089        TESLA      = add(MagneticFluxDensity.class, null,                  magneticFlux.divide(area),    "T",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1090        HENRY      = add(ElectricInductance.class,  null,                  magneticFlux.divide(current), "H",   (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1091        LUX        = add(Illuminance.class,         null,                  luminous.divide(area),        "lx",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1092        LUMEN      = add(LuminousFlux.class,        null,                  luminous,                     "lm",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1093        CANDELA    = add(LuminousIntensity.class,   null,                  luminous,                     "cd",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));    // Must be after Lumen.
1094        MOLE       = add(AmountOfSubstance.class,   null,                  amount,                       "mol", (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1095        STERADIAN  = add(SolidAngle.class,          null,                  dimensionless,                "sr",  (byte) (SI | PREFIXABLE));
1096        /*
1097         * All Unit<Dimensionless>.
1098         */
1099        ConventionalUnit<Dimensionless> bel;
1100        PIXEL   = add(Dimensionless.class, Scalar.Dimensionless::new, dimensionless, "px",  OTHER);
1101        PERCENT = add(one, centi,                                                    "%",   OTHER);
1102        PPM     = add(one, micro,                                                    "ppm", OTHER);
1103        bel     = add(one, PowerOf10.belToOne(), "B", (byte) (ACCEPTED | PREFIXABLE));
1104        DECIBEL = add(bel, Prefixes.converter('d'), "dB", ACCEPTED);
1105        UNITY   = UnitRegistry.init(one);  // Must be last in order to take precedence over all other units associated to UnitDimension.NONE.
1106
1107        UnitRegistry.alias(ARC_MINUTE,  "'");
1108        UnitRegistry.alias(ARC_SECOND, "\"");
1109        UnitRegistry.alias(KELVIN,      "K");       // Ordinary "K" letter (not the dedicated Unicode character).
1110        UnitRegistry.alias(CELSIUS,     "℃");
1111        UnitRegistry.alias(CELSIUS,   "Cel");
1112        UnitRegistry.alias(FAHRENHEIT,  "℉");
1113        UnitRegistry.alias(GRAD,      "gon");
1114        UnitRegistry.alias(HECTARE,   "hm²");
1115        UnitRegistry.alias(LITRE,       "l");
1116        UnitRegistry.alias(LITRE,       "ℓ");
1117        UnitRegistry.alias(UNITY, SystemUnit.ONE);
1118
1119        initialized = true;
1120    }
1121
1122    /**
1123     * Invoked by {@code Units} static class initializer for registering SI base and derived units.
1124     * This method shall be invoked in a single thread by the {@code Units} class initializer only.
1125     *
1126     * @param  quantity   the type of quantity that uses this unit (should not be null).
1127     * @param  factory    the factory to use for creating quantities, or {@code null} if none.
1128     * @param  dimension  the unit dimension.
1129     * @param  symbol     the unit symbol, or {@code null} if this unit has no specific symbol.
1130     * @param  scope      {@link UnitRegistry#SI}, {@link UnitRegistry#ACCEPTED}, other constants or 0 if unknown.
1131     */
1132    private static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> SystemUnit<Q> add(Class<Q> quantity, ScalarFactory<Q> factory,
1133            UnitDimension dimension, String symbol, byte scope)
1134    {
1135        return UnitRegistry.init(new SystemUnit<>(quantity, dimension, symbol, scope, factory));
1136    }
1137
1138    /**
1139     * Invoked by {@code Units} static class initializer for registering SI conventional units.
1140     * This method shall be invoked in a single thread by the {@code Units} class initializer only.
1141     *
1142     * <p>The {@code target} argument should be an instance of {@link SystemUnit}.
1143     * The only exception is for creating the {@link DECIBEL} unit base on the bel conventional unit.</p>
1144     *
1145     * <p>If the {@code target} unit holds a list of {@linkplain SystemUnit#related() related units}
1146     * (i.e. conventional units that can not be computed easily by appending a SI prefix), then the new
1147     * conventional unit is added to that list of related units. For example "foot" is related to "metre"
1148     * and "degree Celsius" is related to "Kelvin", but "kilometre" is not recorded as related to "metre"
1149     * because this relationship can be inferred automatically without the need of a {@code related} table.
1150     * The unrecorded units are all SI units related to {@code target} by a scale factor without offset.</p>
1151     */
1152    private static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> ConventionalUnit<Q> add(AbstractUnit<Q> target, UnitConverter toTarget, String symbol, byte scope) {
1153        final ConventionalUnit<Q> unit = UnitRegistry.init(new ConventionalUnit<>(target, toTarget, symbol, scope));
1154        final ConventionalUnit<Q>[] related = target.related();
1155        if (related != null && (unit.scope != UnitRegistry.SI || !toTarget.isLinear())) {
1156            // Search first empty slot. This algorithm is inefficient, but the length of those arrays is small (<= 7).
1157            int i = 0;
1158            while (related[i] != null) i++;
1159            related[i] = unit;
1160        }
1161        return unit;
1162    }
1163
1164    /**
1165     * Returns the system unit for the given dimension, or {@code null} if none.
1166     * Note that this method can not distinguish the different kinds of dimensionless units.
1167     * If the symbol or the quantity type is known, use {@link #get(String)} or {@link #get(Class)} instead.
1168     *
1169     * <p><b>Implementation note:</b> this method must be defined in this {@code Units} class
1170     * in order to force a class initialization before use.</p>
1171     */
1172    static SystemUnit<?> get(final Dimension dim) {
1173        return (SystemUnit<?>) UnitRegistry.get(dim);
1174    }
1175
1176    /**
1177     * Returns the system unit for the given quantity, or {@code null} if none.
1178     *
1179     * <p><b>Implementation note:</b> this method must be defined in this {@code Units} class
1180     * in order to force a class initialization before use.</p>
1181     */
1182    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1183    static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> SystemUnit<Q> get(final Class<Q> type) {
1184        return (SystemUnit<Q>) UnitRegistry.get(type);
1185    }
1186
1187    /**
1188     * Returns the system unit for the given symbol, or {@code null} if none.
1189     * This method does not perform any parsing (prefix, exponents, <i>etc</i>).
1190     * It is only for getting one of the pre-defined constants, for example after deserialization.
1191     *
1192     * <p><b>Implementation note:</b> this method must be defined in this {@code Units} class
1193     * in order to force a class initialization before use.</p>
1194     *
1195     * @see Prefixes#getUnit(String)
1196     */
1197    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1198    static Unit<?> get(final String symbol) {
1199        return (Unit<?>) UnitRegistry.get(symbol);
1200    }
1201
1202    /**
1203     * Do not allows instantiation of this class.
1204     */
1205    private Units() {
1206    }
1207
1208    /**
1209     * Returns {@code true} if the given unit is a linear unit.
1210     * Linear units are convertible to {@link #DEGREE}.
1211     *
1212     * <p>Angular units are dimensionless, which may be a cause of confusion with other
1213     * dimensionless units like {@link #UNITY} or {@link #PPM}. This method take care
1214     * of differentiating angular units from other dimensionless units.</p>
1215     *
1216     * @param  unit  the unit to check (may be {@code null}).
1217     * @return {@code true} if the given unit is non-null and angular.
1218     *
1219     * @see #ensureAngular(Unit)
1220     */
1221    public static boolean isAngular(final Unit<?> unit) {
1222        return (unit != null) && unit.getSystemUnit().equals(RADIAN);
1223    }
1224
1225    /**
1226     * Returns {@code true} if the given unit is a linear unit.
1227     * Linear units are convertible to {@link #METRE}.
1228     *
1229     * @param  unit  the unit to check (may be {@code null}).
1230     * @return {@code true} if the given unit is non-null and linear.
1231     *
1232     * @see #METRE
1233     * @see #ensureLinear(Unit)
1234     */
1235    public static boolean isLinear(final Unit<?> unit) {
1236        return (unit != null) && unit.getSystemUnit().equals(METRE);
1237    }
1238
1239    /**
1240     * Returns {@code true} if the given unit is a pressure unit.
1241     * Pressure units are convertible to {@link #PASCAL}.
1242     * Those units are sometime used instead of linear units for altitude measurements.
1243     *
1244     * @param  unit  the unit to check (may be {@code null}).
1245     * @return {@code true} if the given unit is non-null and a pressure unit.
1246     */
1247    public static boolean isPressure(final Unit<?> unit) {
1248        return (unit != null) && unit.getSystemUnit().equals(PASCAL);
1249    }
1250
1251    /**
1252     * Returns {@code true} if the given unit is a temporal unit.
1253     * Temporal units are convertible to {@link #SECOND}.
1254     *
1255     * @param  unit  the unit to check (may be {@code null}).
1256     * @return {@code true} if the given unit is non-null and temporal.
1257     *
1258     * @see #ensureTemporal(Unit)
1259     */
1260    public static boolean isTemporal(final Unit<?> unit) {
1261        return (unit != null) && unit.getSystemUnit().equals(SECOND);
1262    }
1263
1264    /**
1265     * Returns {@code true} if the given unit is a dimensionless scale unit.
1266     * This include {@link #UNITY} and {@link #PPM}.
1267     *
1268     * @param  unit  the unit to check (may be {@code null}).
1269     * @return {@code true} if the given unit is non-null and a dimensionless scale.
1270     *
1271     * @see #UNITY
1272     * @see #ensureScale(Unit)
1273     */
1274    public static boolean isScale(final Unit<?> unit) {
1275        return (unit != null) && unit.getSystemUnit().equals(UNITY);
1276    }
1277
1278    /**
1279     * Makes sure that the specified unit is either null or an angular unit.
1280     * This method is used for argument checks in constructors and setter methods.
1281     *
1282     * @param  unit  the unit to check, or {@code null} if none.
1283     * @return the given {@code unit} argument, which may be null.
1284     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code unit} is non-null and not an angular unit.
1285     *
1286     * @see #isAngular(Unit)
1287     */
1288    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1289    public static Unit<Angle> ensureAngular(final Unit<?> unit) throws IllegalArgumentException {
1290        if (unit != null && !isAngular(unit)) {
1291            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonAngularUnit_1, unit));
1292        }
1293        return (Unit<Angle>) unit;
1294    }
1295
1296    /**
1297     * Makes sure that the specified unit is either null or a linear unit.
1298     * This method is used for argument checks in constructors and setter methods.
1299     *
1300     * @param  unit  the unit to check, or {@code null} if none.
1301     * @return the given {@code unit} argument, which may be null.
1302     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code unit} is non-null and not a linear unit.
1303     *
1304     * @see #isLinear(Unit)
1305     */
1306    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1307    public static Unit<Length> ensureLinear(final Unit<?> unit) throws IllegalArgumentException {
1308        if (unit != null && !isLinear(unit)) {
1309            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonLinearUnit_1, unit));
1310        }
1311        return (Unit<Length>) unit;
1312    }
1313
1314    /**
1315     * Makes sure that the specified unit is either null or a temporal unit.
1316     * This method is used for argument checks in constructors and setter methods.
1317     *
1318     * @param  unit  the unit to check, or {@code null} if none.
1319     * @return the given {@code unit} argument, which may be null.
1320     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code unit} is non-null and not a temporal unit.
1321     *
1322     * @see #isTemporal(Unit)
1323     */
1324    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1325    public static Unit<Time> ensureTemporal(final Unit<?> unit) throws IllegalArgumentException {
1326        if (unit != null && !isTemporal(unit)) {
1327            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonTemporalUnit_1, unit));
1328        }
1329        return (Unit<Time>) unit;
1330    }
1331
1332    /**
1333     * Makes sure that the specified unit is either null or a scale unit.
1334     * This method is used for argument checks in constructors and setter methods.
1335     *
1336     * @param  unit  the unit to check, or {@code null} if none.
1337     * @return the given {@code unit} argument, which may be null.
1338     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code unit} is non-null and not a scale unit.
1339     *
1340     * @see #isScale(Unit)
1341     */
1342    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1343    public static Unit<Dimensionless> ensureScale(final Unit<?> unit) throws IllegalArgumentException {
1344        if (unit != null && !isScale(unit)) {
1345            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonScaleUnit_1, unit));
1346        }
1347        return (Unit<Dimensionless>) unit;
1348    }
1349
1350    /**
1351     * Multiplies the given unit by the given ratio. For example multiplying {@link #CENTIMETRE} by 254/100 gives
1352     * {@link #INCH}. Invoking this method is equivalent to invoking <code>{@linkplain Unit#multiply(double)
1353     * Unit.multiply}(numerator / denominator)</code> except that the use of a ration of integer values help
1354     * Seshat to improve accuracy when more than one arithmetic operation are chained.
1355     *
1356     * @param  <Q>          the quantity measured by the unit.
1357     * @param  unit         the unit to multiply.
1358     * @param  numerator    the numerator of the multiplication factor.
1359     * @param  denominator  the denominator of the multiplication factor.
1360     * @return the unit multiplied by the given factor.
1361     */
1362    public static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> Unit<Q> multiply(Unit<Q> unit, double numerator, double denominator) {
1363        return unit.transform(LinearConverter.scale(numerator, denominator));
1364    }
1365
1366    /**
1367     * Returns the factor by which to multiply the standard unit in order to get the given unit.
1368     * The "standard" unit is usually the SI unit on which the given unit is based, as given by
1369     * {@link Unit#getSystemUnit()}.
1370     *
1371     * <div class="note"><b>Example:</b>
1372     * if the given unit is {@link #KILOMETRE}, then this method returns 1000 since a measurement in kilometres
1373     * must be multiplied by 1000 in order to give the equivalent measurement in the "standard" units
1374     * (here {@link #METRE}).</div>
1375     *
1376     * If the given unit is {@code null} or if the conversion to the "standard" unit can not be expressed
1377     * by a single multiplication factor, then this method returns {@link Double#NaN}.
1378     *
1379     * @param  <Q>   the quantity measured by the unit, or {@code null}.
1380     * @param  unit  the unit for which we want the multiplication factor to standard unit, or {@code null}.
1381     * @return the factor by which to multiply a measurement in the given unit in order to get an equivalent
1382     *         measurement in the standard unit, or NaN if the conversion can not be expressed by a scale factor.
1383     */
1384    public static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> double toStandardUnit(final Unit<Q> unit) {
1385        return AbstractConverter.scale(unit == null ? null : unit.getConverterTo(unit.getSystemUnit()));
1386    }
1387
1388    /**
1389     * Creates a linear converter from the given scale and offset.
1390     *
1391     * @param  scale   the scale factor, or {@code null} if none (default value of 1).
1392     * @param  offset  the offset, or {@code null} if none (default value of 0).
1393     * @return a converter for the given scale and offset.
1394     */
1395    public static UnitConverter converter(final Number scale, final Number offset) {
1396        return LinearConverter.create(scale, offset);
1397    }
1398
1399    /**
1400     * Returns the coefficients of the given converter expressed as a polynomial equation.
1401     * This method returns the first of the following choices that apply:
1402     *
1403     * <ul>
1404     *   <li>If the given converter {@linkplain UnitConverter#isIdentity() is identity}, returns an empty array.</li>
1405     *   <li>If the given converter shifts the values without scaling them (for example the conversion from Kelvin to
1406     *       Celsius degrees), returns an array of length 1 containing only the offset.</li>
1407     *   <li>If the given converter scales the values (optionally in addition to shifting them), returns an array of
1408     *       length 2 containing the offset and scale factor, in that order.</li>
1409     * </ul>
1410     *
1411     * This method returns {@code null} if it can not get the polynomial equation coefficients from the given converter.
1412     *
1413     * @param  converter  the converter from which to get the coefficients of the polynomial equation, or {@code null}.
1414     * @return the polynomial equation coefficients (may be any length, including zero), or {@code null} if the given
1415     *         converter is {@code null} or if this method can not get the coefficients.
1416     */
1417    @SuppressWarnings("fallthrough")
1418    public static Number[] coefficients(final UnitConverter converter) {
1419        if (converter != null) {
1420            if (converter instanceof AbstractConverter) {
1421                return ((AbstractConverter) converter).coefficients();
1422            }
1423            if (converter.isIdentity()) {
1424                return new Number[0];
1425            }
1426            if (converter.isLinear()) {
1427                final double offset = converter.convert(0);  // Should be zero as per JSR-363 specification, but we are paranoiac.
1428                final double scale  = converter.convert(1) - offset;
1429                final Number[] c = new Number[(scale != 1) ? 2 : (offset != 0) ? 1 : 0];
1430                switch (c.length) {
1431                    case 2: c[1] = scale;       // Fall through
1432                    case 1: c[0] = offset;
1433                    case 0: break;
1434                }
1435                return c;
1436            }
1437        }
1438        return null;
1439    }
1440
1441    /**
1442     * Returns the derivative of the given converter at the given value,
1443     * or {@code NaN} if this method can not compute it.
1444     *
1445     * @param  converter  the converter for which we want the derivative at a given point, or {@code null}.
1446     * @param  value      the point at which to compute the derivative.
1447     * @return the derivative at the given point, or {@code NaN} if unknown.
1448     */
1449    public static double derivative(final UnitConverter converter, final double value) {
1450        return AbstractConverter.derivative(converter, value);
1451    }
1452
1453    /**
1454     * Parses the given symbol. Invoking this method is equivalent to invoking
1455     * {@link UnitFormat#parse(CharSequence)} on a shared locale-independent instance.
1456     * The list of symbols supported by this method is implementation-dependent
1457     * and may change in future Seshat versions.
1458     *
1459     * @param  uom  the symbol to parse, or {@code null}.
1460     * @return the parsed symbol, or {@code null} if {@code uom} was null.
1461     * @throws ParserException if the given symbol can not be parsed.
1462     *
1463     * @see UnitFormat#parse(CharSequence)
1464     */
1465    public static Unit<?> valueOf(String uom) throws ParserException {
1466        return (uom != null) ? UnitFormat.INSTANCE.parse(uom) : null;
1467    }
1468}
